The Act titled "America's Border Security Act of 2007" includes provisions for technological assets. The Act "America's Border Security Act of 2007" mandates increased use of Department of Defense equipment for surveillance at US borders to prevent illegal immigration. The "America's Border Security Act of 2007" mandates increased use of Department of Defense equipment for surveillance at US borders to prevent illegal immigration. The Secretary of Homeland Security and the Secretary of Defense must submit a report to Congress within 6 months detailing the current use of equipment, risks to citizens and foreign policy interests, and a plan to enhance surveillance efforts. The report to Congress must include details on the types of equipment and support to be provided by the Secretary of Defense for surveillance activities at US borders. Additionally, a pilot program for Unmanned Aerial Vehicles will be conducted by the Secretary of Homeland Security for a 1-year period. The Secretary of Homeland Security will conduct a pilot program using unmanned aerial vehicles for border surveillance along the US-Canada border. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 to carry out this program, with a reminder that the use of the Army or Air Force is prohibited under section 1385 of title 18, United States Code. SEC. 3. INFRASTRUCTURE.

The Secretary of Homeland Security will construct roads, acquire barriers, and facilities to control US borders. Quarterly progress reports will be submitted to Congress. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008-2012 for this purpose. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to construct additional ports of entry along the international land borders of the United States and make necessary improvements to existing ports of entry. The Secretary of Homeland Security is tasked with developing a plan to enhance communication capabilities among Border Patrol agents and various border security agencies using satellite communications and other technologies. This includes improving communication between agents conducting operations, with their stations, residents in remote areas, and with state, local, and tribal law enforcement agencies. The Secretary of Homeland Security is responsible for improving communication between Border Patrol agents and border security agencies, including state, local, and tribal law enforcement agencies. SEC. 6. UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLES. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to acquire and maintain at least 5 unmanned aerial vehicles and related equipment for patrolling the US international borders. This includes additional sensors, critical spares, satellite command and control, and other necessary operational support equipment. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2008 and 2009 to fund these activities. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to receive necessary funds for fiscal years 2008 and 2009 to carry out the acquisition and maintenance of unmanned aerial vehicles for border patrolling. The appropriated funds are authorized to remain available until expended. SEC. 7. SURVEILLANCE TECHNOLOGIES PROGRAMS. The Secretary of Homeland Security must develop and implement an aerial surveillance program to enhance border security with unmanned aerial vehicles along the US-Canada and US-Mexico borders. The Secretary of Homeland Security is tasked with developing a program for continuous monitoring of the US-Canada and US-Mexico borders using aerial surveillance technologies to address border threats. The Secretary of Homeland Security will consult with the Secretary of Defense and the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration regarding the deployment of technologies along international borders and implementation of the monitoring program. The program developed under this subsection will include the use of aerial surveillance technologies in various topographies and areas, including those near international borders, to evaluate different circumstances. The program will assess the significance, cost, effectiveness, and concerns of using various technologies for border security near international borders. The Secretary of Homeland Security may continue using aerial surveillance technologies for border security while assessing their effectiveness. A report on the program must be submitted to Congress within 180 days of implementation, addressing liability, safety, and privacy concerns. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to establish a program for additional unmanned aerial surveillance, with a report to Congress including program details and recommendations for improvement. Appropriations are authorized for this purpose. The Secretary of Homeland Security is mandated to establish the Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program to procure various technologies for border control and create a "virtual fence" to prevent illegal immigration. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program aims to integrate technologies for border control, including motion sensor alerts and automated cameras that pan and tilt towards triggered sensors. Cameras in the program do not require manual operation. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program includes cameras that do not need manual operation, have flexible views, and can be viewed at multiple centers. Data collected is standardized, and future technology upgrades can be integrated with existing systems. Future remote surveillance technology investments and upgrades for the Program can be integrated with existing systems. Performance measures will evaluate if the Program is achieving desired results in monitoring and detecting illegal intrusions along US borders. Plans will streamline site selection, validation, and environmental assessment processes to minimize delays. The Program aims to streamline site selection, validation, and environmental assessment processes to minimize delays in installing surveillance technology infrastructure. Standards are developed to expand shared use of existing structures and deploy nonpermanent surveillance platforms for increased mobility in identifying illegal activities. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program aims to enhance the Secretary's ability to identify illegal border intrusions. The Secretary of Homeland Security must report to Congress within a year of the program's implementation, providing a description and any recommendations for improvement. Additionally, there are standards in place for evaluating contractors involved in the program. The Secretary of Homeland Security will develop standards to evaluate contractors for the Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program. The Inspector General will review new contracts related to the program. The Department will review new contracts for the Program over $5,000,000 to ensure compliance with cost requirements, performance objectives, and schedules. The Inspector General will report findings to the Secretary of Homeland Security promptly. The Inspector General will report findings to the Secretary of Homeland Security, who must submit a report to the Senate and House Committees within 30 days. The Inspector General will report findings to the Secretary of Homeland Security, who must submit a report to the Senate and House Committees within 30 days. Authorization of appropriations is provided for necessary funds to implement this subsection. SEC. 8. Hiring and training of border and transportation security personnel. During fiscal year 2008, the Secretary of Homeland Security is required to increase the number of full-time agents and support staff in the Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement by 400, and the number of full-time inspectors and support staff in the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection by 600. The Secretary is authorized to waive any limitation on the number of full-time equivalent positions. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to waive limitations on personnel to increase the number of full-time inspectors and support staff in the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection by 600. Ongoing training is required to ensure proficiency levels and utilization of new technologies for border protection. SEC. 9. NATIONAL BORDER SECURITY PLAN. The Secretary of Homeland Security must prepare and submit a National Border Security Plan to Congress by January 31 each year. The plan should include a vulnerability assessment of each port of entry and consultation with relevant agencies and entities involved in international trade across the northern and southern borders. The National Border Security Plan must include a vulnerability assessment of each port of entry on the northern or southern border. Port security coordinators may be established to assist in conducting these assessments and preparing the required plan.
